name: Take this Pride and Prejudice Quiz! Easy Trivia | Austen, Jane

questions.text: What are the Bennet sisters' names, from eldest to youngest?
options: Elizabeth, Catherine, Elinor, Fanny, Emma, Anne
Elizabeth, Anne, Mary, Henrietta, Louisa
Elinor, Marianne, Margaret, Lucy
questions.explanation:
Jane, Elizabeth, Mary, Kitty, Lydia.

	The two eldest are close friends, and the two youngest like to flirt with officers together. The middle daughter, Mary, is pseudo-scholarly, plain, and pompous.

questions.text: Why did Mr. Bennet marry his wife?
options: She was intelligent and witty.
She had a large fortune.
The two are cousins; their families wished them to marry.
questions.explanation:
She was very pretty.

	Mr. Bennet probably regretted his decision soon after his marriage. The Bennets' marriage is reminiscent of the Palmers' marriage in 'Sense and Sensibility.'

questions.text: Which words best describe Mrs. Bennet?
options: cordial and witty
timid and sickly
sarcastic and introverted
questions.explanation:
vulgar and talkative.

	Mrs. Bennet's chief concern is to get her five daughters married.

questions.text: Who are Elizabeth's two favorite family members?
options: Mr. Collins and Mary
Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Philips
Lydia and Kitty
questions.explanation:
Jane and Mr. Bennet

	Elizabeth is good friends with her eldest sister and she enjoys her father's wit and intelligence. However, she is aware of mistakes Mr. Bennet makes.

options: Mrs. Bennet's brother
Mr. Darcy's cousin
Mr. Collins' patron
questions.explanation:
Mr. Bingley's brother-in-law

	Mr. Bingley has two sisters: Miss Caroline Bingley, and Mrs. Hurst.

questions.text: Why does Mr. Collins propose to Charlotte Lucas?
questions.correct: She's nice to him after Elizabeth turns him down.
options: Mr. Collins does not believe cousins should marry.
Charlotte's father is a member of the nobility.
Lady Catherine commands Mr. Collins to marry Charlotte.
questions.explanation:
She's nice to him after Elizabeth turns him down.

	Elizabeth is appalled when her sensible friend Charlotte accepts Mr. Collins' proposal.

questions.text: When does Elizabeth first begin to change her mind about Mr. Darcy?
questions.correct: after she reads his letter concerning Wickham, Jane, and other matters
options: after Lady Catherine commands her not to become engaged to Darcy
during the time she is nursing Jane at Netherfield
after she first sees Pemberley
questions.explanation:
after she reads his letter concerning Wickham, Jane, and other matters.

	As soon as Elizabeth realizes that some of her assumptions about Darcy are incorrect, she begins to become aware of his good qualities.

questions.correct: Apparently, Mr. Darcy gives him money.
options: Wickham is deeply in love with Lydia.
Mr. Bennet challenges him to a duel.
Mr. Gardiner persuades him to marry her.
questions.explanation:
Apparently, Mr. Darcy gives him money.

	After Elizabeth tells Darcy of her family's trouble, he goes to London, finds Wickham and Lydia (living in sin, presumably), and makes it worth Wickham's while to marry the youngest Miss Bennet.

questions.text: What ultimate effect does Lady Catherine's visit to Elizabeth have on Darcy?
questions.correct: It makes him aware that Elizabeth may be willing to marry him.
options: It convinces him not to marry Elizabeth after all, since E. is rude to Lady C.
It convinces him that Elizabeth's family is not as vulgar as he had once thought.
It makes him realize what a kind, loving aunt Lady Catherine is.
questions.explanation:
It makes him aware that Elizabeth may be willing to marry him.

	Lady Catherine means to prevent her nephew's marriage to Elizabeth, but her visit has the opposite effect.

questions.text: How does Mrs. Bennet feel about Elizabeth's engagement to Darcy?
questions.correct: Since he is so wealthy, she is absolutely thrilled.
options: Since she knows her beloved Wickham and Darcy are enemies, she's angry.
She disapproves because she doesn't like him.
Since she still wishes E. had married Mr. Collins, she's lukewarm about it.
questions.explanation:
Since he is so wealthy, she is absolutely thrilled.

	Mrs. Bennet has always disliked Darcy for his disdainful behavior, but as soon as he becomes engaged to Elizabeth, Mrs. B. does an about face (since Darcy is even richer than Bingley).
